description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Asia Pacific region is impacted by environmental stress resulting from climate change, large scale development projects, urban excess, pollution, deforestation, water scarcity and overfishing among others. Communities affected often lack information of the environmental challenges they are facing which would allow them to voice their concern over the negative environmental effects of large scale projects as well as to increase their resilience to the impacts of climate change. Existing environmental information is often unintelligible to the public and policy-makers. The voices of those most vulnerable to the effects of climate change – women, youth, and indigenous communities- are marginalised and rarely heard in either local or international media. Environmental journalists and local environmental activists not seldom work in isolation and without support, and may be disconnected from larger global conversations. Moreover, communication infrastructure tends poor at local level. Media workers lack funds, time and expertise and are facing ill-equipped research institutions, or reluctance by authorities to provide open data.
Internews’ Earth Journalism Network (EJN)’s overarching goal is that policy makers, people and communities use new knowledge to develop better environmental policies and natural resource management plans. EJN aims to boost the quantity and quality of environmental media coverage in the Asia-Pacific region. The approaches include training programmes, fellowships to major environmental summits, sub-grants, story stipends, open data webpage development. The expected results includes:
1) Improved reliable access for public, communities, policy makers to diverse sources of socio-environmental information 2) Improved quantity and quality of socio-environmental information 3) Increased inclusion of women and marginalized groups in socio-environmental media and information 4) Increased peer to peer & multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing and/or collaboration around socio-environmental information
The outputs include: - 45 Organizational Grants – Awarded to local media partners, CSOs, NGOs or other grass-roots groups for local capacity-building, networking, content production, etc. - 152 Special Project Awards - grants awarded to individuals/groups, freelancers, videographers, bloggers, entrepreneurs, data journalists, CSOs groups, start-ups and other “non-outlet” groups applying to do socio-environmental projects. - 120 Story Grants – Awarded to individual journalists for production of news and feature pieces. - Training of Trainers for 200 journalists – to build local leadership and enhance the regional network of environmental media partners, editors, trainers and mentors - Around 4,000 trainees trained for producing quality socio-environmental information per year - Around 1,000,000 hits of audience reached globally per year - Climate Change Media Partnership (CCMP) Fellowships – awarded each year to a dozen leading journalists from the region to attend and cover the annual UNFCCC climate summits, enabling them to engage at the global level, and greatly build their capacity - GeoJournalism – Development and Maintenance of regional websites dedicated to environmental coverage of key regions, including the use of visualized data and other innovative digital media techniques. - Relevant research projects (identified during the implementation phase)
Sweden will support EJN from 2017-2021, with the budget as of SEK 46 801 000.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Miljön i Asien och Stillahavsområdet påverkas av klimatförändringar, storskaliga utvecklingsprojekt, städers utbredning, föroreningar, avskogning, vattenbrist och överfiske. Människor saknar ofta information om de miljöproblem som påverkar dem, information som skulle göra det möjligt för dem att uttrycka sin oro över negativa miljöeffekter av storskaliga projekt och att öka deras motståndskraft mot klimatpåverkan. Befintlig miljöinformation är ofta svår att förstå för allmänheten och beslutsfattare. Rösterna från de mest utsatta för klimatförändringarnas effekter - kvinnor, ungdomar och inhemska samhällen - marginaliseras och hörs sällan i lokala eller internationella medier. Miljöjournalister och lokala miljöaktivister arbetar ofta isolerat och utan stöd och kan inte koppla in i de större globala samtalen. Dessutom tenderar kommunikationsinfrastrukturen att vara dålig på lokal nivå. Media-folk saknar medel, tid och expertis och står ofta inför dåligt utrustade forskningsinstitut och motstånd från myndigheterna att tillhandahålla öppna data.
Internews Earth Journalism Network (EJN) s övergripande mål är att beslutsfattare, människor och samhällen använder ny kunskap för att utveckla bättre miljöpolicy och planer för naturresurshantering. EJN syftar till att öka kvantiteten och kvaliteten på miljörapportering i Asien-Stillahavsområdet. Tillvägagångssätten omfattar utbildningar, stipendier till större miljötoppmöten, delbidrag, stipendier och utveckling av webb för öppen data. De förväntade resultaten inkluderar: 1) Förbättrad tillförlitlig tillgång för allmänheten, samhällen och beslutsfattare till olika källor till socio-miljöinformation 2) Förbättrad mängd och kvalitet av socio-miljöinformation 3) Ökad inkludering av kvinnor och marginaliserade grupper i socio-miljömedia och information 4) Ökad kunskapsdelning och / eller samverkan kring samhälls-miljöinformation
Outputs inkluderar: - 45 Organisationsbidrag - Tilldelas lokala mediapartners, CSOs, icke-statliga organisationer eller andra gräsrotsgrupper för lokal kapacitetsuppbyggnad, nätverk, innehållsproduktion etc. - 152 Särskilda Projektutmärkelser - Beviljade bidrag till individer / grupper, frilansare, videografer, bloggare, entreprenörer, dataloggare, CSO-grupper, nystartade företag och andra "icke-uttag" -grupper som ansöker om att göra socio-miljöprojekt. - 120 Story Grants - Tilldelas individuella journalister för produktion av nyheter och särdrag. - Utbildning av tränare för 200 journalister - Att bygga lokalt ledarskap och förbättra det regionala nätverket av miljömediapartner, redaktörer, tränare och mentorer - Cirka 4000 praktikanter utbildade för att producera kvalitativ socio-miljöinformation per år - Omkring 1 000 000 publikum träffades globalt per år - Medlemmar av klimatförändringsmedier (CCMP) - utdelas varje år till ett dussin ledande journalister från regionen för att delta i och täcka de årliga klimat toppmötena för FN: s klimatkonvention, vilket gör det möjligt för dem att engagera sig på global nivå och kraftigt bygga upp sin kapacitet - GeoJournalistik - Utveckling och underhåll av regionala webbplatser som är avsedda för miljöskydd av nyckelområden, inklusive användandet av visualiserad data och andra innovativa digitala medietekniker. - Relevanta forskningsprojekt (identifierade under genomförandefasen) Sverige kommer att stödja EJN från 2017-2021, med budgeten 46 801 000 kronor.

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
14.1 - Till 2025 förebygga och avsevärt minska alla slags föroreningar i havet, i synnerhet från landbaserad verksamhet, inklusive marint skräp och tillförsel av näringsämnen.
14.1 - By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
6.b - Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.
6.b - Stödja och stärka lokalsamhällenas deltagande i arbetet med att förbättra vatten- och sanitetshanteringen.

description.narrative: The results of Internews/ Earth Journalism Network in the Asia-Pacific project (EJN were achieved both quantitively and qualitatively during 1 September 2018 to 31 August 2019. The environmental stories were disseminated through this project to more than 1.2 million pageviews on topics of the environmental crisis to the public, especially the communities vulnerable to environmental degradation and climate change, loss of biodiversity, air and ocean pollution, the environmental impacts of large-scale development, sustainable consumption. The story grants were provided to 82 individual journalists, 693 original stories being produced and 43 training courses being conducted for 1094 journalists (498 females) in environmental reporting. Additionally, 12 new organizations were supported to implement projects that strengthened local coverage of key socio-environmental issues. The scholarships were provided to 12 Asian-Pacific journalists for new coverages during the Global Climate Action Summit (GCAS) in San Francisco and UN FCCC COP 24 in Poland. The impact of the media reporting towards the policy makers can be found in Thailand and Pakistan. In Thailand, stories produced by Isaan Record led to the termination of discharge of toxic wastewater from a landfill that was polluting local farmland; in Pakistan, the story on the dangers of heatwave to slum dwellers led to the legalization of the slum which gave slum dwellers access to much needed public services. Aside from these outcomes, several journalists that have been part of this project have received awards, in recognition of their outstanding journalism. The assessment based on each outcome area is detailed as following: Expected Outcome 1. Policymakers, communities and global audiences have improved reliable access to diverse sources of socio-environmental information Achieved: By the end of Year 2, the project has exceeded its target of 1 million additional pageviews. In the span of two years, it has provided reliable access to environmental related stories to more than a million users through six secure websites reaching around 2.4 million pageviews by the end of August 2019. These figures are underreported since many of the stories are also disseminated through mainstream media outlets, and EJN is unable to track their reach. Expected Outcome 2. Media organisations have improved quantity and quality of socio-environmental information Achieved: The project has exceeded the targets of the two indicators under this outcome. In the first two years of the project, EJN has produced 975 original stories in total (693 in Year 2 and 264 in Year 1), higher than the target of 700 stories. In terms of quality, findings from the mid-term content analysis of stories also indicate an improvement in the overall quality of the original stories published on EJN’s three GeoJournaliam websites (Ekuatorial, Mekong Eye, and The Third Pole). The percentage of stories meeting Internews’ standards increased from 35% in the baseline to 68% in the midline. The standards have been evaluated based on 1. Governance & management 2. Administration 3. Business & financial sustainability 4. Programme Management 5. Programme Delivery 6. Collaboration and Networks 7. Content Production and Dissemination 8. Technology and Digital Security Capacity. Expected Outcome 3. Media organisations increasingly include women and marginalised groups in socio-environmental content and information Partly achieved: The project has achieved the target of the main indicator under this outcome, which measures the percentage of stories supported by the project with content and information inclusive of women or other marginalised groups. The findings from the mid-term content analysis indicate an improvement in the percentage of stories with content inclusion of women and marginalized groups, from 49% in the baseline to 70% in the midline. However, despite the improvement, the average scores of the three analysed website content for the criteria ‘inclusion of women’ and ‘inclusion of marginalized groups’ remain lower than Internews’ standard. EJN is required to pay more attention to improve content in these two areas in the second half of the project. The method on ‘how’ is still piloting. In the next reporting period, the project will develop tools to analyse how and when women appeared in media sources and assess in what extent EJN is helping to include diverse women’s voices in the news reporting. Expected Outcome 4. Journalists, media networks and other environmental actors increasingly collaborate and share knowledge around socio-environmental information Achieved: EJN has met the targets for the knowledge sharing and networking related outputs stated under this outcome in the logical framework. These are the number of networks supported and the number of spaces for multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing facilitated. They have conducted and facilitated many peer-to-peer engagements and multi-stakeholder knowledge sharing and/or collaboration activities, examples include the various thematic workshops in South Asia, the climate change workshops in the Pacific, Belt and Road media workshops, and the annual Training of Trainers/Managers. Highlight: The highlight of this reporting period is the set up of special reporting projects addressing impacts of China’s Belt Road Initiative (BRI). Belt Watch is a series of stories examining the socio-environmental ramifications of China’s BRI. The media coverage of the BRI is often inadequate to monitor its social and environmental impacts. Hence the Belt Watch special reporting project is aimed to address this gap. Between September 2018 to August 2019, EJN supported and published 13 stories from Sri Lanka, Thailand, Laos, India, Myanmar, Bangladesh, Nepal and Pakistan. This project will continue until the next reporting periods due to its high relevance to the regional development. Dialogue issues: In addition to a gender equality, the environmental perspective is a main dialogue area. The EJN environmental simplified assessment was submitted in February 2020 and the Embassy asked the Environmental Helpdesk to review. Overall, the EJN’s simplified environmental assessment is of very good quality and is highly relevant for environmental sustainability. The way that Internews has addressed environmental issues in their work could be used as inspiration for other Sida partners involved in media and journalism that sometimes struggles how to integrate environmental issues in their work.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
